content:
This is really too hard for a clash, I didn't manage to finish the loop part in 15 minutes but had the best result with 57%,
This could have been an easy puzzle, but for a clash the first cases wihtout a loop would have already set it in the hard clashes
I've just removed {{,}} from Goal and Constraints sections (an issue previously pointed out by @StepBack13 and @Aldoggen but not fixed by the author).

Consider: "n[0[]+:=1-]0="
When n is a nonnegative integer, this sequence of instructions should print the integers from n to 0, inclusive, in decreasing order. When n = 0, your code fails with an IndexError without printing 0.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Is a good practice work

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Yeah pretty good

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is great and familiar to most codingamers

Solved it. I think this is definitely very hard for clash of code, but maybe doable for the real pros. I  really like the amount of test cases. Good work! I'm probably not gonna approve this until more people have deemed the difficulty appropriate. I would support an easy/medium puzzle version of this, like StepBack13 talked about.

* People glossing over your statement (like I did, trying to implement it as quickly as possible) might miss the fact that you need to jump *after* the corresponding "]". Could you maybe try highlighting the word "after" in <<bold>>? It might jump out too much, so use at your own discretion.
* You should probably add somewhere that all outputs should be on the same line, without any separator character.
* Your string of allowed characters still contains a comma (both in the goal statement and in the constraints), which you probably want to remove.

This is definitely too hard for Reverse.

I tried it and thought I was getting somewhere but then it turned out I was not at all. Looked at the statement and realised this is way too complex to reverse-engineer.

The statement never explains what "," does, but it doesn't seem to appear in tests. Also, "Peek the stack" isn't explained either. "top of stack" is also ambiguous for someone who hasn't learned about stack-based programming. You also don't explain that "/" is integer division. You also don't explain that if you see multiple "=" then you print output on the same line, without spaces/newlines. Then when you get to the loops, it's a whole new level of difficulty after getting past all the previous hurdles... then I see you've even got nested loops! ಠ_ಠ

I think this looks too hard for a clash, really. I don't think someone who isn't already well-versed in such languages could solve this in 15 minutes from this statement.  It would make a nice Easy puzzle, though.

Thank you for your feedback! Yes maybe I should resubmit it as an easy puzzle instead.

Do you think it could be a good clash, fastest and shortest but not reverse, if I only kept instructions:
0123456789+-*:=.
?

Ie, push numbers, add sub mul (but not div), duplicate, output as integer, output as ascii.

100% agree. I should have rejected it, but I always try to give people a chance to fix it before rejecting.

I just got it in a clash and got 57% too, even after having moderated it. Got beaten by two bots. :/

And then maybe a separate reverse clash with only:
0123456789+-*

ie, push numbers, add sub mul, no other instruction, the testcases would be so that there is always exactly one number remaining on the stack at the end, and the goal is to output that number.

I think the simplifications for Fastest/Shortest would probably be ok, a little on the hard side but doable.

For Reverse, it's maybe doable with those extra simplifications, but the hardest part is really understanding how the stack works without a statement explaining that it's a stack. It's easy enough when it's just individual operations "23+=", "56*=", but when you perform operations on the results it can get confusing without knowing what's happening. I first tried to solve this with repeated RegEx substitutions and the issue was that if you replace "57*" with "35" then it's hard to parse the next operation because you've got a multi-digit result. e.g. "57*23*-=" -> "356-=" then it's unclear whether to do "3-56" or "35-6" etc. Of course, it's not a good way to solve this, but in Reverse mode, people often try naive solutions like that... expecting them to guess that they need to use a real stack might be asking a bit too much without explaining it.

But if I just keep digits and +-* then it's just reverse polish notations. It doesn't leave that much to guess.

I could also give a little bit of hint int the stub, like print(top of stack) or something

And if you've already understood from the first testcases what to do when they're a single operation, I think it should be clear that
25*34+-
results in (2*5)-(3*4), even if you haven't thought of using a stack to implement it
It's worth submitting, if you are willing to split it into three. I just think that Reverse might be expecting a bit too much, but others might think it's fine.
